In secondary school chemistry class we had an interesting demo of how explosive nitrogen triiodide is, followed by a lecture on other nitro-halides....it is really interesting that as you go higher in the periodic table you go from nitrogen trifluoride (gas, not very toxic, bit reactive, quite useful), through nitrogen trichloride (liquid, pungent, explosive, slightly useful), nitrogen triiodide (solid, extremely unstable, explosive, not very useful) up to nitrogen tribromide (insanely unstable, explosive even at -100C, no uses whatsoever)....unfortunately no-one has ever isolated the next element up (Astatine) because it is so radioactive and unstable but it makes me wonder how nitrogen triastatatinide would behave....
